template: {CHARACTER_0} had some stickers. After giving 15 to {CHARACTER_1} and receiving 8 from {CHARACTER_2}, {CHARACTER_0} now has 23 stickers. How many stickers did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} share marbles in ratio 3:5. After {CHARACTER_1} gives 6 marbles to {CHARACTER_0}, they have equal amounts. How many marbles did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} spent 1/3 of money on lunch and 1/4 on snacks. If {CHARACTER_0} has $25 left, how much money did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} scored 75% in a test. If {CHARACTER_0} got 5 more marks, the score would be 85%. How many questions were in the test?

{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} have 180 cards. {CHARACTER_0} has twice as many as {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} has 20 more than {CHARACTER_1}. How many cards does {CHARACTER_0} have?
The average age of {CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} is 12 years. If {CHARACTER_2} is 15 years old, what is the average age of {CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1}?
{CHARACTER_0} has coins in ratio of 2:3:5 for bronze, silver, and gold coins. If {CHARACTER_0} has 15 gold coins, how many coins does {CHARACTER_0} have in total?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} start 120m apart and walk towards each other. {CHARACTER_0} walks at 4m/s and {CHARACTER_1} at 6m/s. After how many seconds will they meet?
{CHARACTER_0} read 2/5 of a book on Monday and 1/3 of the remainder on Tuesday. If 24 pages are left, how many pages are in the book?
{CHARACTER_0} bought a game on sale at 20% discount for $64. What was the original price?
{CHARACTER_0} saw chickens and rabbits in a farm. There are 12 heads and 32 legs in total. How many rabbits are there?
{CHARACTER_0} counted 20 bicycles and tricycles at the park. If there are 50 wheels in total, how many tricycles are there?
{CHARACTER_0} bought adult tickets at $8 each and child tickets at $5 each for a total of 15 tickets. If {CHARACTER_0} spent $99, how many adult tickets were bought?
{CHARACTER_0} has a collection of 25 coins made up of 20-cent and 50-cent coins worth $9.50 in total. How many 50-cent coins are there?
In {CHARACTER_0}'s class, there are spiders (8 legs) and beetles (6 legs). There are 10 creatures with 74 legs in total. How many spiders are there?

{CHARACTER_0} has chickens and ducks. There are 18 birds and 50 legs. If chickens have 2 legs and ducks have 2 legs, but {CHARACTER_0} counted wrong and some 'ducks' are actually geese with 2 legs each standing on one leg, giving the appearance of 32 total standing legs instead. How many are chickens? (Note: All birds have 2 legs, there are 18 birds total)
{CHARACTER_0} counted chickens and rabbits. There are 15 heads total. If all were chickens, there would be 30 legs. But there are actually 44 legs. How many rabbits are there?
{CHARACTER_0} has stamps worth either 50 cents or 80 cents each. There are 30 stamps worth $18 in total. How many 80-cent stamps does {CHARACTER_0} have?
{CHARACTER_0} bought pens at $2 each and erasers at $1 each. If {CHARACTER_0} bought 24 items for $38, how many pens were bought?
{CHARACTER_0} saw chickens and cows in a farm. There are 28 legs and 9 animals. How many chickens are there?

{CHARACTER_0} wants to pack stickers into bags. If 5 stickers are put in each bag, there will be 3 stickers left over. If 6 stickers are put in each bag, 1 more sticker is needed. How many stickers are there?
{CHARACTER_0} is arranging students into teams. If 4 students per team, there are 2 students without a team. If 5 students per team, one team will be short of 3 students. How many students are there?

{CHARACTER_0} wants to give candies to children. If each child gets 7 candies, {CHARACTER_0} will have 5 candies left. If each child gets 9 candies, {CHARACTER_0} will need 7 more candies. How many children are there?
{CHARACTER_0} distributes marbles to friends. Giving 8 marbles each leaves 5 marbles remaining. Giving 11 marbles each requires 7 more marbles. How many marbles does {CHARACTER_0} have?
{CHARACTER_0} packs books into boxes. Using 12 books per box leaves 7 books over. Using 15 books per box means the last box has only 4 books. How many books are there?
{CHARACTER_0} wants to seat people at tables. With 6 people per table, 2 people have no seats. With 7 people per table, there are 5 empty seats. How many people are there?
{CHARACTER_0} groups stickers into sets. Making sets of 8 leaves 3 stickers remaining. Making sets of 11 means the last set has only 6 stickers. How many stickers does {CHARACTER_0} have?
{CHARACTER_0} arranges chairs in rows. With 9 chairs per row, there are 4 chairs left over. With 10 chairs per row, {CHARACTER_0} needs 5 more chairs. How many chairs are there?
{CHARACTER_0} distributes cards to players. Giving 5 cards each leaves 8 cards unused. Giving 7 cards each means {CHARACTER_0} is short by 4 cards. How many players are there?
{CHARACTER_0} packs toys into bags. Using 6 toys per bag leaves 2 toys remaining. Using 8 toys per bag means the last bag has only 4 toys. How many toys are there?
{CHARACTER_0} noticed a pattern: 2, 5, 11, 23, 47, ... Each number follows a rule. What is the next number?
{CHARACTER_0} arranges squares: Row 1 has 1 square, Row 2 has 3 squares, Row 3 has 5 squares, Row 4 has 7 squares. How many squares are in Row 10?
{CHARACTER_0} found the sequence: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, ... What is the 8th term?
{CHARACTER_0} observes: 3, 6, 12, 24, 48, ... What number comes next in this pattern?
{CHARACTER_0} sees the pattern: 5, 8, 14, 26, 50, ... What is the next number?
{CHARACTER_0} builds triangle patterns. Pattern 1 uses 3 sticks, Pattern 2 uses 5 sticks, Pattern 3 uses 7 sticks. How many sticks are needed for Pattern 12?
{CHARACTER_0} continues the sequence: 2, 6, 12, 20, 30, ... What is the 7th term?
{CHARACTER_0} notices: 1, 3, 7, 15, 31, 63, ... What is the next number?
{CHARACTER_0} counts dots in patterns: Pattern 1 has 4 dots, Pattern 2 has 7 dots, Pattern 3 has 10 dots. How many dots are in Pattern 15?
{CHARACTER_0} finds the pattern: 100, 94, 87, 79, 70, ... What comes next?
{CHARACTER_0} plants trees along a 120m road with one tree every 15m, including both ends. How many trees are planted?
{CHARACTER_0} places lamp posts along both sides of a 200m street, with posts 25m apart. If there are posts at both ends, how many lamp posts are needed in total?
{CHARACTER_0} plants flowers around a circular garden with circumference 96m. If flowers are planted every 8m, how many flowers are planted?
{CHARACTER_0} hangs flags along a 180m path with a flag every 20m, but NOT at the starting point. How many flags are needed?
{CHARACTER_0} places poles along a 150m fence with poles 10m apart, including both ends. How many poles are needed?
{CHARACTER_0} plants trees in a straight line. The distance from the 1st tree to the 6th tree is 40m. What is the distance between consecutive trees?
{CHARACTER_0} strings lights around a square garden. Each side is 60m long. If lights are placed every 12m including corners, how many lights are needed?
{CHARACTER_0} cuts a log into 9 equal pieces. If each cut takes 2 minutes, how many minutes does {CHARACTER_0} take in total?
{CHARACTER_0} plants trees along a 300m road with trees 30m apart. If there is a tree at the start but NOT at the end, how many trees are planted?
{CHARACTER_0} places markers along a race track every 50m. The track is 400m long (circular). How many markers are placed?
{CHARACTER_0} is 3 times as old as {CHARACTER_1}. In 6 years, {CHARACTER_0} will be twice as old as {CHARACTER_1}. How old is {CHARACTER_0} now?
The sum of {CHARACTER_0}'s and {CHARACTER_1}'s ages is 40. Four years ago, {CHARACTER_0} was 3 times as old as {CHARACTER_1}. How old is {CHARACTER_0} now?
{CHARACTER_0} is 4 years older than {CHARACTER_1}. In 8 years, the sum of their ages will be 40. How old is {CHARACTER_1} now?
{CHARACTER_0}'s age is 5 times {CHARACTER_1}'s age. The difference in their ages is 24 years. How old is {CHARACTER_0}?
Five years ago, {CHARACTER_0} was twice as old as {CHARACTER_1}. Now {CHARACTER_0} is 35 years old. How old is {CHARACTER_1} now?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} are 28 years old together. {CHARACTER_0} is 4 years older than {CHARACTER_1}. How old is {CHARACTER_0}?
In 3 years, {CHARACTER_0} will be twice as old as {CHARACTER_1}. If {CHARACTER_1} is 9 years old now, how old is {CHARACTER_0} now?
{CHARACTER_0} is three times as old as {CHARACTER_1}. If their total age is 48, how old is {CHARACTER_1}?
Four years ago, {CHARACTER_0} was 20 years old. In 6 years, {CHARACTER_1} will be 30. What is the sum of their current ages?
{CHARACTER_0} is 6 years older than {CHARACTER_1}. In 4 years, {CHARACTER_0} will be 22. How old is {CHARACTER_1} now?

{CHARACTER_0} spent 1/4 of money on lunch, then 1/3 of the remainder on a snack, and finally 1/2 of what was left on a drink. If {CHARACTER_0} has $15 left, how much money did {CHARACTER_0} start with?
{CHARACTER_0} gave away 2/5 of stickers to {CHARACTER_1}, then 1/2 of the remainder to {CHARACTER_2}. If {CHARACTER_0} has 24 stickers left, how many stickers did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} read 1/5 of a book on Monday, 1/4 of the remainder on Tuesday, and 1/3 of what was left on Wednesday. If 20 pages remain unread, how many pages are in the book?
{CHARACTER_0} used 3/8 of beads for a bracelet, then 1/2 of the remainder for a necklace, and had 15 beads left. How many beads did {CHARACTER_0} have at the start?
{CHARACTER_0} sold 2/7 of apples in the morning, then 3/5 of the remainder in the afternoon. If 12 apples are left, how many apples did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} spent 1/3 of money on books, then 1/2 of the remainder on games. If $20 is left, how much money did {CHARACTER_0} have originally?
{CHARACTER_0} gave 2/5 of marbles to friends, then lost 1/3 of the remainder. If {CHARACTER_0} has 18 marbles left, how many marbles did {CHARACTER_0} start with?
{CHARACTER_0} drank 1/4 of juice, then {CHARACTER_1} drank 1/3 of what remained. If 300ml is left, how much juice was there at first?
{CHARACTER_0} completed 3/10 of homework, then 1/2 of the remainder before dinner. If 21 questions are left, how many homework questions are there in total?
{CHARACTER_0} ate 1/6 of a cake, {CHARACTER_1} ate 1/5 of the remainder, and {CHARACTER_2} ate 1/4 of what was left. If 9 pieces remain, how many pieces were in the original cake?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} are 120km apart. They travel towards each other at 30km/h and 40km/h respectively. How many hours until they meet?
{CHARACTER_0} travels 45km in 3 hours, then 60km in 2 hours. What is {CHARACTER_0}'s average speed for the entire journey?
{CHARACTER_0} runs at 8km/h and {CHARACTER_1} runs at 6km/h. They start from the same point in opposite directions. After how many minutes will they be 7km apart?
{CHARACTER_0} drives at 60km/h and leaves at 9am. {CHARACTER_1} leaves from the same place at 10am driving at 80km/h in the same direction. At what time will {CHARACTER_1} catch up?
{CHARACTER_0} walks to school at 4km/h and takes 30 minutes. If {CHARACTER_0} cycles at 12km/h instead, how many minutes will it take?
{CHARACTER_0} travels 180km. For the first half of the distance, speed is 60km/h. For the second half, speed is 90km/h. What is the average speed?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} start 150m apart and walk towards each other. {CHARACTER_0} walks at 2m/s and {CHARACTER_1} at 3m/s. How many seconds until they meet?
{CHARACTER_0} drives 240km at 80km/h. If {CHARACTER_0} wants to reduce travel time by 1 hour, what should the new speed be?
{CHARACTER_0} jogs at 9km/h for 40 minutes, then walks at 5km/h for 30 minutes. What is the total distance covered?
{CHARACTER_0} cycles at 15km/h from home to school. The return journey at 10km/h takes 15 minutes longer. How far is school from home?
{CHARACTER_0} has a rectangle with perimeter 48cm. If the length is twice the width, what is the area?
{CHARACTER_0} has a square with area 144cm². If {CHARACTER_0} increases each side by 4cm, what is the new area?
{CHARACTER_0} has a rectangular garden 15m by 10m. A path 1m wide runs around the inside edge. What is the area of the path?
{CHARACTER_0} makes a rectangle with area 72cm² and perimeter 36cm. What is the length of the longer side?
{CHARACTER_0} has a square field with side 20m. If {CHARACTER_0} increases the side by 25%, what is the increase in area?
{CHARACTER_0} cuts a rectangle 24cm by 18cm into identical small squares with no waste. What is the largest possible side length of each small square?
{CHARACTER_0} has a rectangular plot 16m by 12m. A concrete path 2m wide surrounds it on the outside. What is the area of the path?
{CHARACTER_0} has two squares. The larger square has sides 3cm longer than the smaller. If the difference in their areas is 39cm², what is the side of the smaller square?
{CHARACTER_0} increases the length of a rectangle by 20% and decreases the width by 20%. The original area was 100cm². What is the new area?
{CHARACTER_0} has a rectangle where length is 5cm more than width. If the perimeter is 50cm, what is the area?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have marbles in ratio 5:3. After {CHARACTER_0} gives 12 marbles to {CHARACTER_1}, they have equal amounts. How many marbles did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} has 3 times as much money as {CHARACTER_1}. After {CHARACTER_0} spends $45 and {CHARACTER_1} spends $15, they have equal amounts. How much did {CHARACTER_1} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have stickers in ratio 7:5. After {CHARACTER_1} receives 8 stickers from {CHARACTER_2}, the ratio becomes 7:6. How many stickers did {CHARACTER_1} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} has $20 more than {CHARACTER_1}. After {CHARACTER_0} gives {CHARACTER_1} some money, {CHARACTER_0} has $12 less than {CHARACTER_1}. How much did {CHARACTER_0} give?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have cards in ratio 4:3. After {CHARACTER_0} gives 7 cards to {CHARACTER_1}, the ratio becomes 3:4. How many cards do they have in total?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have money in ratio 7:5. After both spend $14, the ratio becomes 3:2. How much did {CHARACTER_0} have initially?
{CHARACTER_0} has twice as many books as {CHARACTER_1}. After {CHARACTER_1} buys 15 more books, they have the same number. How many books did {CHARACTER_0} have?

{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} have stickers in ratio 5:4:3. After {CHARACTER_0} gives 6 to {CHARACTER_2}, all three have equal amounts. How many stickers did {CHARACTER_0} have initially?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have stamps in ratio 3:7. After {CHARACTER_0} receives 20 stamps, the ratio becomes 1:1. How many stamps did {CHARACTER_0} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have coins in ratio 8:5. After {CHARACTER_0} loses 20 coins and {CHARACTER_1} gains 10 coins, they have equal amounts. How many coins did {CHARACTER_1} have at first?
{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} share money in ratio 2:3:5. If {CHARACTER_2} receives $60 more than {CHARACTER_0}, what is the total amount shared?

The ratio of {CHARACTER_0}'s savings to {CHARACTER_1}'s savings is 5:3. The ratio of {CHARACTER_1}'s savings to {CHARACTER_2}'s savings is 4:5. If {CHARACTER_2} has $60, how much does {CHARACTER_0} have?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} have marbles in ratio 5:7. {CHARACTER_1} and {CHARACTER_2} have marbles in ratio 3:2. If {CHARACTER_0} has 30 marbles, how many does {CHARACTER_2} have?
The ratio of flour to sugar to butter in a recipe is 6:3:2. If {CHARACTER_0} uses 450g of flour, how much sugar and butter combined does {CHARACTER_0} need?
{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} have ages in ratio 3:4:5. If their total age is 72, how old is {CHARACTER_1}?
The ratio of red to blue to green marbles is 4:5:6. After {CHARACTER_0} adds 10 red marbles, the ratio of red to blue becomes 6:5. How many blue marbles are there?

{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} share money in ratio 4:3:2. After {CHARACTER_1} gives $6 to {CHARACTER_2}, {CHARACTER_1} and {CHARACTER_2} have equal amounts. What was the total money shared?
The ratio of {CHARACTER_0}'s stickers to {CHARACTER_1}'s stickers is 2:3, and {CHARACTER_1}'s to {CHARACTER_2}'s is 5:4. If the total is 111 stickers, how many does {CHARACTER_0} have?
{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} share 240 cards in ratio 3:5:8. How many more cards does {CHARACTER_2} have than {CHARACTER_0}?
In a class, the ratio of boys to girls is 3:2. The ratio of students who wear glasses to those who don't is 2:3. If there are 15 boys, how many students are there in total?
{CHARACTER_0} bought a toy at $80 with a 20% discount. What was the original price?
{CHARACTER_0} sells an item at $144 making a 20% profit. What was the cost price?
{CHARACTER_0} increases a number by 25%, then decreases the result by 20%. The final number is 120. What was the original number?
{CHARACTER_0} got 75% in Test 1 and 80% in Test 2. If Test 1 had 40 questions and Test 2 had 50 questions, what percentage did {CHARACTER_0} get overall?
{CHARACTER_0} bought a phone for $800 and sold it at a 15% loss. {CHARACTER_1} bought it from {CHARACTER_0} and sold it for $850. What was {CHARACTER_1}'s profit percentage?
{CHARACTER_0} increased savings by 40% from last year to have $420 now. How much did {CHARACTER_0} have last year?
{CHARACTER_0} marks up an item by 50% then gives a 20% discount. If the selling price is $120, what was the cost price?
{CHARACTER_0} scored 60 marks out of 80 in Test 1 and 45 marks out of 60 in Test 2. Which test had a better percentage?
{CHARACTER_0} decreases a price by 10%, then increases it by 10%. The final price is $99. What was the original price?
{CHARACTER_0} bought an item for $200 and wants to make a 30% profit after giving a 20% discount. What should be the marked price?
{CHARACTER_0} has a rectangular tank 20cm by 15cm by 10cm filled with water. If {CHARACTER_0} pours it into a tank with base 25cm by 12cm, what is the water level?
{CHARACTER_0} fills a tank at 5 liters per minute. If the tank is 80cm by 50cm by 60cm, how many minutes to fill it completely?
{CHARACTER_0} has a cube with side 6cm. If it's melted and recast into a cuboid 9cm by 4cm, what is the height?
{CHARACTER_0} pours water from a full tank 30cm by 20cm by 25cm into identical bottles of 500ml each. How many bottles can be filled?
{CHARACTER_0} has two identical cubes each with volume 64cm³. If they are joined to form a cuboid, what is the surface area of the cuboid?
{CHARACTER_0} fills a tank with two pipes. Pipe A fills at 6 liters/min and Pipe B at 4 liters/min. If the tank holds 300 liters, how long to fill using both pipes?
{CHARACTER_0} has a container 40cm long, 25cm wide with water 12cm deep. After adding a stone, water rises to 15cm. What is the volume of the stone?
{CHARACTER_0} has a rectangular tank 50cm by 40cm. Water is 20cm deep. How many 8cm cubes can be submerged before water overflows if the tank is 30cm tall?
{CHARACTER_0} has a tank with base area 600cm². If 18 liters of water are poured in, what is the water level in cm?
{CHARACTER_0} has a cuboid 12cm by 10cm by 8cm. If a smaller cube with side 4cm is cut from one corner, what volume remains?
{CHARACTER_0} can complete a job in 12 days. {CHARACTER_1} can do it in 15 days. Working together, how many days will it take?
{CHARACTER_0} can paint a fence in 8 hours. After working 4 hours, {CHARACTER_1} joins and they finish together in 2 more hours. How long would {CHARACTER_1} take alone?
{CHARACTER_0} fills a pool in 5 hours. A drain empties it in 15 hours. If both operate together, how long to fill the empty pool?
{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} can complete work in 10, 12, and 15 days respectively. Working together, how many days will it take?
{CHARACTER_0} types 40 pages in 2 hours. {CHARACTER_1} types 50 pages in 2 hours. Working together, how many pages can they type in 3 hours?
{CHARACTER_0} can do a job in 20 days. After 5 days, {CHARACTER_1} joins. They finish the remaining work in 5 days. How many days would {CHARACTER_1} take alone?
{CHARACTER_0} makes 24 toys in 6 hours. At this rate, how many hours to make 60 toys?
Pipe A fills a tank in 4 hours. Pipe B fills it in 6 hours. If Pipe A runs for 2 hours, how much longer does Pipe B need to finish filling?
{CHARACTER_0} reads 30 pages per hour. {CHARACTER_1} reads 40 pages per hour. Starting together, after how many hours will {CHARACTER_1} be 20 pages ahead?
{CHARACTER_0} can build a wall in 15 days working 6 hours daily. How many days to complete if working 9 hours daily?
{CHARACTER_0} has a number that leaves remainder 3 when divided by 5, and remainder 4 when divided by 7. What is the smallest such number?
{CHARACTER_0} divides marbles equally among 8 friends with 5 left over. Dividing among 11 friends leaves 8 over. What is the smallest number of marbles?
{CHARACTER_0} has candies. Grouping by 6 leaves 4 remaining. Grouping by 8 leaves 6 remaining. What is the smallest number of candies?
{CHARACTER_0} numbered pages of a book. The digit 5 was written 25 times. How many pages are there if the book starts from page 1?
{CHARACTER_0} shares stickers among friends. Groups of 6 leave 2 extra. Groups of 8 leave 4 extra. If there are between 50 and 80 stickers, how many are there?
{CHARACTER_0} has a number less than 100. Dividing by 4 leaves 3, dividing by 5 leaves 4, dividing by 6 leaves 5. What is the number?
{CHARACTER_0} arranges books in rows of 12 with 7 left over. In rows of 15, there are 10 left over. How many books if there are fewer than 100?
{CHARACTER_0} counts in groups of 5 (3 left), groups of 6 (4 left), and groups of 7 (5 left). What is the smallest such number?
{CHARACTER_0} has coins. When counted by 8s, 5 remain. When counted by 12s, 9 remain. What is the smallest number of coins?
{CHARACTER_0} writes numbers from 1 to N. The digit 7 appears exactly 20 times. What is N?

{CHARACTER_0} is 3 times as old as {CHARACTER_1}. The difference in their ages is 18 years. How old is {CHARACTER_0}?
{CHARACTER_0} has $50 more than {CHARACTER_1}. {CHARACTER_0} has twice as much as {CHARACTER_1}. How much does {CHARACTER_1} have?
The length of a rectangle is 5 times its width. The perimeter is 72cm. What is the length?
{CHARACTER_0} has 5 times as many stamps as {CHARACTER_1}. If {CHARACTER_0} has 45 more stamps than {CHARACTER_1}, how many does {CHARACTER_1} have?
{CHARACTER_0} scored 3 times what {CHARACTER_1} scored. Their total score is 160. What did {CHARACTER_0} score?

The sum of two numbers is 84. One number is 3 times the other. What is the smaller number?

4 books and 2 pens cost $37. 2 books and 3 pens cost $23.50. How much does 1 book cost?
{CHARACTER_0} bought 6 notebooks and 4 pencils for $22. One notebook costs $2 more than one pencil. What is the cost of 1 notebook?
3 chairs and 2 tables cost $250. 2 chairs and 1 table cost $140. What is the cost of 1 table?
{CHARACTER_0} paid $29 for 4 small toys and 3 large toys. {CHARACTER_1} paid $39 for 2 small toys and 5 large toys. What is the cost of 1 large toy?
2 kg of rice and 3 kg of sugar cost $16. 4 kg of rice and 2 kg of sugar cost $24. What is the cost of 1 kg of rice?
{CHARACTER_0} bought 8 roses and 5 lilies for $46. Each rose costs $3. What is the cost of 1 lily?
3 markers and 4 crayons cost $20.50. 4 markers and 2 crayons cost $19. What is the cost of 1 marker?
{CHARACTER_0} bought some $5 notes and $10 notes totaling $120 with 18 notes. How many $10 notes did {CHARACTER_0} get?
{CHARACTER_0}, {CHARACTER_1}, and {CHARACTER_2} finished a race. {CHARACTER_0} was not first. {CHARACTER_2} was not last. {CHARACTER_1} finished after {CHARACTER_0}. What was the order?
{CHARACTER_0} says: 'I have twice as many as {CHARACTER_1}.' {CHARACTER_1} says: 'Together we have 30.' How many does {CHARACTER_0} have?
Three friends scored 150 points total. {CHARACTER_0} scored 10 more than {CHARACTER_1}. {CHARACTER_1} scored 10 more than {CHARACTER_2}. What did {CHARACTER_1} score?
{CHARACTER_0} and {CHARACTER_1} are among 5 people in a line. There are 2 people between them. If {CHARACTER_0} is 2nd, what position is {CHARACTER_1}?
